gov.ornl.keva.table

Class TableValue

  • java.lang.Object
    • gov.ornl.keva.table.TableValue
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    TableBucket, TableDeleteOp, TableEmbedded, TableExternal

    public class TableValue
extends java.lang.Object
    Base class for all table values. Table values are the atomic data stored in memtables. In Keva, table value can have a specific data type (defined in the key). This is useful if the user wants to store more than just a simple byte array.
    Author:
    James Horey

    • Field Detail

      • EMBED

        public static final short EMBED
        The different types of values. Embedded data just means that the actual data is in the buffer. External data contains information where to find the data chunks.
        See Also:

      • setStorageType

        public void setStorageType(short type)
        The storage type describes the broad category of the table value. For example, whether it's embedded, external, or user-defined.
        Parameters:
        type - Storage type

      • setClock

        public void setClock(VectorClock clock)
        Set the vector clock for this value. All values must be associated with a vector clock.
        Parameters:
        clock - Vector clock

      • getClock

        public VectorClock getClock()
        Get the vector clock associated with this value.
        Returns:
        Vector cloci

      • incClock

        public void incClock(byte[] id)
        If a vector clock is already associated with this value, increment the vector clock. Otherwise create a new clock with the client ID.
        Parameters:
        id - Client ID

      • getData

        public byte[] getData()
        Get all the data associated with this value.

      • getValue

        public TableValue getValue(VectorClock clock)
        Get the value associated with the supplied vector clock. Really only makes sense for buckets.

      • memory

        public long memory()
        Get the memory usage of the data. This is usually the same as the "size", but not always.
        Returns:
        Bytes used
